bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, November 28, 1892

div1.p: Reed offers advice for Blincoe's daughter, Laura. He discusses his personal finances, and regrets that he cannot send her money.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, November 28, 1892
div1.opener:
Headquarters Department of Dakota,
ATTENDING SURGEON'S OFFICE.
St. Paul, Minn., Nov. 28th, 1892,
My darling Sister:
div1.p:
The day after
I received your dear letter,
I sat down and wrote to
your little Mexican girl,
“su Chiquita Mexicana”, a
funny letter, intended to
cheer her up and make her
cacchinate just a little bit.
I know that she is having
a good, happy time, for she
must be busily occupied
and gaining new experiences-
every day. Indeed, Mexico,
as the land of the Aztecs,
has long been to me an
extremely interesting country, and
one which I have much de-
sired to visit; & intend to
do so, whenever I can get
the opportunity. Now as to
Juanita's Medicine, she can
take them continuously for
many weeks, without any
danger- I shall be very
glad to hear that she is im-
proving. I trust that before
this, Pa has been to see
you and that you have
had a nice chat together.
How I should like to see
the dear old gentleman!
What an exquisite appetite
he had when I last sat with
him around his own board!
Indeed, I therein saw most
wonderful vitality for a man
of his years vitality; Would that
I could lead such an use-
ful life! He is the salt of the
earth, and you, my dear Sister,
are the Salter!

“Now to business,” as the little
bee said when the small
boy caught him between
his toes. I fully agree with
you that it is good to let each
other know how we stand finan-
cially, and since you have told
me about your things terrestrial,
I am going to let you in behind
the scenes a little. Then we
will both have a better un-
derstanding all around.

I am now, while in St. Paul,
on a salary of $252.67 per month.
I live in an apartment at the
“Albian”, for which I pay $65.00
rent per month - our board
is $100 per month - our washing
$10.00- We pay a servant $2.50
per month to thoroughly clean apart-
ments once a week - Blossom's
music is $5.00 per month and rent
of piano $6.00 per month- In addition
I am paying monthly $65.00 on my
lot for a home in Hagerstown
Md. I have been making monthly
payments on this piece of ground
for a home since Novr 1890, and it
will take till Decr 31st '94 to finish
it- If you will add these items together
you will see that they amount to
$251.00 per month, leaving me the
suny little sum of $1.67 on which
to “cavort” - add to this $11.80 which
I get for my monthly allowance
of coal and this is increased to
$13.47 above actual expenses-
I only tell you these things, my
Darling Sister, be so that if, at any
time, you should wonder why dear
brother W. doesn't open his fat
purse, you will understand
that he has to “scratch” oc-
casionally as well as other folks,
we would go to housekeeping
but this would be more
expensive yet. But notwith
standing all these things, you
certainly shall have some
share of that $13.67 once in
a while- Lawrence & I, each,
save $3.00 street-car fare per
month by walking- But he
is a sturdy boy and don't
mind it, and your “Uncle Edward”
is not to be “sneezed at”
on the pedestrian question either-
St. Paul is an expensive town
to live in; but never mind,
if I can only get through
'93 & '94 safely, my head should
once more be well out of
water- '93 will be my hardest
year, as I expect my next
promotion in '94, when my
salary will be increased
$50.00 per month- I felt as
if I must tell you these things
so that you would understand
my situation. If you should be
in need of necessaries, don't, for
the world, fail to tell me, at
once, for I can get the money
on a pinch- As soon as the
month's debts are settled, I will
cast up my accounts and see
if I can't help you with a few
dollars- This letter is only in-
-tended for your & Anita's eyes.
God bless you all & keep
you well- Please write
very soon- Your letters are
always so welcome-

Love from us all, to you and
Yours,
div1.closer:
Your loving brother, Walter. P.S. Don't for
the world let
this letter make
you sad for
I am "as chipper
as a jay bird".
W.
